newsitem.title: UK: North Sea crude premiums slump on oversupply.
newsitem.headline: North Sea crude premiums slump on oversupply.

text.p: North Sea crude premiums slumped on Tuesday as an overhang of prompt cargoes met with thinning demand from refiners, traders said.
December Brent recovered its early losses to trade up seven cents on the day at $24.71 per barrel, but physical premiums fell by over 10 cents in many cases.
An Oseberg cargo loading at the end of October traded at Dated Brent +25 cents, 13 cents below Monday's sale of a Nov 4-6 loader.
A Forties cargo loading on Nov 4-6 was sold at Dated +22 cents, 32 cents below Friday's traded level.
And Dated Brent loading Nov 6-8 fell to parity to Nov paper.
"It's coming off hard today and I don't know if we've seen the bottom yet," a major North Sea equity holder said.

One trader, who already held about five Brent cargoes, was bidding for the Nov 6-8 Brent at Nov +15 cents, but this was seen as a specific requirement and going somewhat against the recent weaker trend. The trader said he was buying for system requirements, but also kept an eye on the U.S. arbitrage.
Tuesday's sole Brent date was kept by Esso, dealers said.
The slide in premiums was not restricted to the prompt period only, as a Nov 7-9 Forties cargo traded at Dated +25 cents.
Urals in the Mediterranean held around dated -60/-55 cents with 2-3 large cargoes for sale. Planned pipeline maintenance of 3-4 days at Novorossiisk was thought by some to have started on Tuesday.

Nigeria's Qua Iboe was under some pressure with a cargo loading today heard still unsold but overall West African light crudes were balanced in a market where most refiners were already covered for the first half of November.
Syrian negotiations continued with the best offer at dated Brent -5 cents fob Syria while lifters held off 15 cents lower. "The negotiations are very tough,' one lifter said.
